div1.p: Truby identifies the men in a photograph taken at Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, October 3, 1944
div1.opener:
C
O
P
Y
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
October 3, 1944.
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I was pleased to get your letter of September 1 enclosing the
copy of Walter Reed's New Years Eve letter to his wife in 1900. I
was also very much pleased to see the photograph of the group around
the ambulance at Camp Lazear. That was very familiar to me. I am
returning the photograph with remarks on the back of it. No. 2 is
certainly Dr. Cooke. I am quite sure that No. 3 is Jernegan. No. 4
is, I am quite sure, acting steward, Kissinger. Notice his chevrons.
The picture certainly looks exactly like Kissinger's outline and is
not at all like the two other acting stewards we had in Cuba. No. 6
is evidently a young officer in a blue flannel shirt and officer's
blue uniform cap. I have no idea who it is. After studying this
photograph a long time, I am almost certain that No. 7 is Walter
Reed himself, although I never saw Walter Reed wear civilian clothes
in Cuba. This was evidently one of those cold days there when woolen
uniforms felt comfortable. If that is Kissinger in the picture, it
means that this photograph was taken late in December or in January,
for Kissinger was promoted after his attack of Yellow Fever. Reed
probably had no blue uniforms with him but had civilian clothes to
wear after he left the boat in New York on his way to Washington.
The three men (No. 10) look exactly like the Spanish volunteers. The
boys were evidently their friends who could visit them at that place.
I hope you will get Dr. Cooke to express his views and you should al-
so ask the Reed family if No. 7 is really Reed.
